severity_classification_principles.description: Core principles for incident severity assessment

bullets.content: Always think step-by-step and explain reasoning before providing severity classification
Justify severity assessment based on scope, business impact, and customer exposure
Distinguish between unplanned outages and planned maintenance windows when assessing severity

scope_analysis.description: How to analyze incident scope and its impact on severity

bullets.content: Internal-only scope with no customer exposure typically reduces severity to low, even when functionality is down
Global scope typically indicates high severity, but planned maintenance or acceptable degradation can reduce it to medium
Regulatory and compliance issues create exceptions to standard severity rubrics - override normal scope considerations

contextual_factors.description: Critical contextual factors that modify severity assessment

bullets.content: Business timing context (Black Friday, peak hours) can elevate identical technical issues from medium to critical
Deployment correlation (error spike within minutes of deployment) indicates high-confidence rollback path and justifies higher severity
Gradual degradation requires projecting future state based on trend - act before crisis even if current metrics look healthy
Recovery window (time until business impact) reduces urgency - weekend batch job failures with Monday deadline are low severity

signal_filtering.description: How to separate signal from noise in incident reports

bullets.content: Filter user perception ('broken') from technical reality (slow but functional) - distinguish degradation from outage
Identify red herrings - unrelated alerts or symptoms that don't share root cause with primary incident
Link symptoms to active maintenance windows or change requests - expected degradation is not an emergency
Green availability dashboards can hide critical data integrity failures - prioritize data correctness over uptime metrics
Payment failures are permanent (no retry, no fallback) - even low error rates (8%) are critical due to revenue hemorrhage
Data integrity violations are worse than downtime - silent corruption returning wrong data is more dangerous than honest errors
Planned API deprecation with adequate notice (90 days) is medium severity despite customer complaints - partner responsibility issue

common_pitfalls.description: Mistakes to avoid in severity assessment

bullets.content: Don't let alarming language in user reports ('broken', 'down') override technical analysis of actual functionality
Don't assume low percentages (8% error rate) are acceptable without domain context - in payments, this is catastrophic
Don't ignore climbing error trends (2% â†’ 8%) - trajectory matters as much as current state
Don't confuse single-user scope with low severity when regulatory/compliance issues are involved
